required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.official_title: Molecular Imaging of Plaque Vulnerability Using 18F-choline PET-MRI in Carotid Artery Atherosclerosis Patients

brief_summary.textblock: Accumulating data in the literature suggests that radiolabeled-choline (18F-choline) is a sensitive molecular tracer for PET imaging that is taken up in activated cells and, as such, is able to identify active inflammatory sites. The investigators hypothesize that 18F-choline is also highly taken up in vulnerable plaques in comparison to the stable ones.

detailed_description.textblock:
Accumulation and subsequent activation of inflammatory cells in the atherosclerotic plaques play an essential role in transforming a stable plaque into a vulnerable plaque at risk to rupture. On this basis, the study aims to evaluate the diagnostic performance of 18F-choline PET in identifying ongoing inflammation within atherosclerotic plaques. The investigators hypothesize that 18F-choline PET is efficient in detecting intraplaque inflammation and identify vulnerable plaques that are prone to rupture in comparison to the stable ones.
It is likely that by correlating the inflammatory status of an atherosclerotic plaque (on 18F-choline PET) with the presence of other vulnerable plaque features (on MR imaging) would be of high clinical relevance for clinical diagnosis of vulnerable plaques.

primary_outcome.measure: 18F-choline uptake, as marker of plaque inflammation
primary_outcome.description: • To assess on PET the uptake of 18F-choline tracer in the symptomatic carotid artery plaque, given as Target-to-Background uptake Ratio (TBR);

primary_outcome.measure: correlate the intra-plaque uptake of 18F-choline on PET with the total area of CD68-positivity within the symptomatic plaque
primary_outcome.description: • In case of carotid surgery, to correlate the intra-plaque uptake of 18F-choline on PET with the total area of CD68-positivity within the symptomatic plaque, as a measure of plaque inflammation and vulnerability on histology

primary_outcome.measure: sensitivity, specificity, negative predictive value of 18F-choline PET
primary_outcome.description: • To determine the sensitivity, specificity, negative predictive value of 18F-choline PET in diagnosis of vulnerable plaques.

secondary_outcome.measure: Correlation of F18-Choline uptake vs other histologic plaque parameters.
secondary_outcome.description: • In case of carotid surgery, to correlate the intra-plaque 18F-choline uptake on PET with other histologic plaque parameters besides inflammation, such as the total area of intra-plaque lipid core, haemorrhage, fibrous tissue and calcifications;

secondary_outcome.measure: Correlation of F18-Choline uptake vs PET and MRI parameters of atherosclerotic plaque
secondary_outcome.description: • To correlate the intra-plaque 18F-choline uptake on PET and MRI parameters of atherosclerotic plaque, such as % of intra-plaque fibrous tissue, lipid core, hemorrhage, calcifications;

secondary_outcome.measure: Correlation of F18-choline plaque uptake vs 18F-FDG uptake
secondary_outcome.description: • To correlate the intra-plaque 18F-choline uptake on PET with the already established FDG PET imaging parameters of atherosclerotic plaque, such as inflammation;
• To compare on PET the 18F-choline uptake in the symptomatic carotid plaque with the uptake in the asymptomatic contralateral carotid artery.

secondary_outcome.measure: Correlation of F18choline plaque uptake vs cardiovascular risk profile
secondary_outcome.description: • To evaluate a possible association between the degree of 18F-choline uptake on PET with patients' cardiovascular risk profile and medical history.

arm_group.description: Intervention: 18F-choline PET-MR imaging. Drug: 18F-choline, dosis 4 MBq/kg body-weight (maximum 360 MBq), administered intravenously as a single dose. Procedure: dynamic and static 18F-choline PET-MR.

reference.citation: Bucerius J, Schmaljohann J, Böhm I, Palmedo H, Guhlke S, Tiemann K, Schild HH, Biersack HJ, Manka C. Feasibility of 18F-fluoromethylcholine PET/CT for imaging of vessel wall alterations in humans--first results. Eur J Nucl Med Mol Imaging. 2008 Apr;35(4):815-20. doi: 10.1007/s00259-007-0685-x. Epub 2008 Jan 6.

Kato K, Schober O, Ikeda M, Schäfers M, Ishigaki T, Kies P, Naganawa S, Stegger L. Evaluation and comparison of 11C-choline uptake and calcification in aortic and common carotid arterial walls with combined PET/CT.
